frameDefinitions: This frame concerns an Evaluee being judged for its quality, i.e. how much it would probably be liked.
These words refer to separating a Whole into Parts, or separating one part from another.
A Speaker addresses an Addressee with a Message, which may be indirectly referred to as a Topic.
A Communicator communicates a judgment of an Evaluee to an Addressee.
An Inspector directs his/her perceptual attention to a Ground to ascertain whether the Ground is intact or  whether an Unwanted_entity is present.
An Assessor examines a Phenomenon to figure out its Value according to some Feature of the Phenomenon.
frameExamples: I <t>divided</t> the class into groups in alphabetical order .
I <t>commended</t> his handling of the crisis.
The police removed Flonnory and Barbour from the automobile and <t>frisked</t> them for weapons.
Each company is then <t>evaluated</t> for their earning potential. CNI
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Evaluee</fen> is being judged for its quality.
This role marks expressions that denote a scalar property of the <fen>Evaluee</fen> with respect to which the <fen>Evaluee</fen> is judged.
The <fen>Whole</fen> is a single entity or an aggregate of entities which is separated into <fen>Parts</fen>.  It is usually the NP Object of a target verb.
This refers collectively to the Parts resulting from separation of a Whole:
Part-1 is the first of two Parts mentioned. This is most often the Object of a verb.
<fen>Part_2</fen> is the second of two <fen>Parts</fen> mentioned. This is usually a PP Complement. First,
With causative uses of these verbs, an Agent separates or divides something.  The Agent is usually expressed as the External Argument:
The <fen>Cause</fen> is the non-agent that brings about the separation.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the separation occurs.
Where the separation occurs.
The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that produces the <fen>Message</fen>.
The <fen>Addressee</fen> receives the <fen>Message</fen> from the <fen>Speaker</fen>.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the communication produced by the <fen>Speaker</fen>.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is a general description of the content of the <fen>Message</fen>.
This role is the <fen>Medium</fen> in which the <fen>Message</fen> is expressed.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> informs the <fen>Addressee</fen> of the <fen>Message</fen>.
<fen>Place</fen> is the location in which the <fen>Speaker</fen> informs  the <fen>Addressee</fen> of the <fen>Message</fen>.
The <fen>Communicator</fen> uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey his or her evaluation of the <fen>Evaluee</fen> to another person.
<fen>Medium</fen> identifies the physical or abstract setting in which the evaluation is conveyed.
<fen>Topic</fen> identifies the entity to which the proposition or propositions conveyed relate.
A judgment is made about the <fen>Evaluee</fen>  With verbs this role is typically expressed as Object:
<fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part that conveys the judgment made by the <fen>Communicator</fen>.
Typically, there is a constituent expressing the <t>Reason</t> for the <fen>Communicator</fen>'s judgment. It is usually a <ment>for</ment>-PP.
When the communication of the judgment takes place.
Where the communication of the judgment takes place.
The person who inspects the <fen>Ground</fen> to see if it is intact or without blemish.
The entity that the <fen>Inspector</fen> inspects with his senses to ascertain whether it is intact.
An entity whose presence would impair the acceptability or usefulness of the <fen>Ground</fen>.

Some of the words in this frame occur with a constituent that expresses the desired outcome of the inspection.  Normally this constituent is a PP Complement headed by <ment>for</ment>, or a <ment>to</ment>-marked VP Complement.
The desirable state of affairs which the <fen>Inspector</fen> hopes to find to obtain when inspecting the <fen>Ground</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Inspector</fen> examines the <fen>Ground</fen>.
The sentient entity that evaluates the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The entity whose <fen>Value</fen> according to a <fen>Feature</fen> is being measured.
The type of property or feature that the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is being judged on.
An event or procedure that allows the <fen>Assessor</fen> to evaluate the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Assessor</fen> to make the assessment.
The time at which the <fen>Assessor</fen> makes the assessment.
The location where the assessing takes place.
listRoleExamples: He gave me another lame <fex>excuse</fex>.
The Beaujolais Nouveau is dazzling <fex>in freshness</fex>.
The directors split <fex>the company</fex> in two.
The directors split the company <fex>in two</fex>.
First, separate <fex>the yolks</fex> from the whites.
separate the yolks <fex>from the whites</fex>.
<fex>The researcher</fex> divided subjects into groups.
I divided the prize money among the winners <fex>that night</fex>.
You should separate the yolks from the whites <fex>over the sink</fex>.
<fex>Bill</fex> told me that he would come to the party.
The authorities informed me <fex>that my brother had been arrested</fex>.
Leroy told his mother <fex>about his arrest</fex>.

Even when we had a size problem they informed me <fex>right away</fex> and everything worked
out great.
She looked at it for a few moments, thinking of Mark Smeaton and what he had told her <fex>on the steps of City Hall</fex>.
<fex>Jon</fex> belittled Madie to her colleagues.
Jon belittled Madie <fex>over the telephone</fex>.
Jon criticized Madie <fex>about her managerial style</fex>.
Jon belittled <fex>Madie</fex> to her colleagues.
She viewed him with a critical <fex>gaze</fex>.
Jon extolled Madie <fex>for her efforts</fex>.
He received critical acclaim <fex>last week</fex>.
He was belittled by his long-time friend <fex>in front of his family</fex>.
<fex>Smithers</fex> proof-read my paper on phlogiston production.
`Mister Thomas' said Holmes, `have you examined <fex>the lock</fex> to determine whether or not it has been forced or otherwise tampered with?'
Security guards frisked all the spectators <fex>for weapons</fex> as they entered the stadium.
Check all gutter brackets and clips <fex>to ensure no water will drip on to the walls</fex>.
Check <fex>that the light is out</fex> before you leave.
<fex>Yesterday</fex> we inspected all the taps and water pipes at animal enclosures being utilized
You will also be graded <fex>on your speed of response</fex> .
<fex>The study</fex> evaluated the risk of a major quake.
<fex>This chapter</fex> evaluates the far-left's contribution to the environmentalism debate since the '70's .
The committee rated Smithers ' most loyal servant ' <fex>about a week ago</fex> .
They 'll evaluate you <fex>in that room over there</fex> , and then you 're free to go .
